docs.snippet: ITEM: In yet another bid to prevent the Soviet Union from disintegrating in its winter of discontent, Mikhail Gorbachev reorganizes his Government and hints that full-blown rationing will be needed to feed the nation.   Item: World trade negotiations...
docs.lead_paragraph: ITEM: In yet another bid to prevent the Soviet Union from disintegrating in its winter of discontent, Mikhail Gorbachev reorganizes his Government and hints that full-blown rationing will be needed to feed the nation. Item: World trade negotiations are on the verge of collapse because European leaders cannot bring themselves to say no to their subsidy-addicted, overproducing farmers.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Let Them Eat Bread

docs.snippet: The original purpose of the 1975 Helsinki conference was to substitute for a World War II German peace treaty, impossible to sign because of two Germanys. So the Soviets settled for a document guaranteeing the postwar borders and, in effect,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The original purpose of the 1975 Helsinki conference was to substitute for a World War II German peace treaty, impossible to sign because of two Germanys. So the Soviets settled for a document guaranteeing the postwar borders and, in effect, recognizing two German states. The U.S wasn't particularly interested, but its European allies led the way, insisting as a tradeoff from the Soviets that the accords include a "third basket" pledging human rights. The agreements of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe were written off as a sellout by the American right since the pledges didn't even provide lip service for democracy.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

docs.snippet: For a composer, an inherited popular culture can serve either as a starting point or as quicksand underfoot. At Jose Caceres's concert at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday night, called "The Piano in Latin America," popular culture did a little of each.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: For a composer, an inherited popular culture can serve either as a starting point or as quicksand underfoot. At Jose Caceres's concert at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday night, called "The Piano in Latin America," popular culture did a little of each. The vivid rhythmic life of Latin music, with all its abrupt changes of mood and movement, lived in all the pieces he played, as did the love of bright coloring and the occasional retensions of Old World modal melody. Composers have a choice here: to take what they want for themselves or to act as servants to more powerful forces, that is, to write pieces that end up as little more than settings for popular song and dance.

headline.main: Review/Music; Latin Rhythms on Piano From Jose Caceres

docs.snippet: Farm ministers from five leading Latin American agricultural exporters today rejected a European Community proposal to cut farm subsidies by 30 percent as part of world trade talks.   Brazil, Argentina, Chile and Uruguay, in a tough statement issued...
docs.lead_paragraph: Farm ministers from five leading Latin American agricultural exporters today rejected a European Community proposal to cut farm subsidies by 30 percent as part of world trade talks. Brazil, Argentina, Chile and Uruguay, in a tough statement issued after two days of talks here, described the European Community proposal to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade as "against the spirit of GATT."

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

docs.snippet: Seeking to capitalize on the warmest official American-Mexican relations in recent memory, Mexican authorities prepared for the arrival of President Bush here on Monday for a two-day state visit that is expected to focus largely on trade issues.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to capitalize on the warmest official American-Mexican relations in recent memory, Mexican authorities prepared for the arrival of President Bush here on Monday for a two-day state visit that is expected to focus largely on trade issues. The visit, which will be the sixth meeting between President Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, is seen here as a confirmation of the good personal ties between the two leaders, who held their first talks even before Mr. Bush was sworn in as President.That theme has dominated descriptions of the meeting by aides to Mr. Salinas, who has staked much of his personal and political success on his ability to work as an equal with Mr. Bush in improving relations between the two countries.

headline.main: Mexicans Hopeful as They Await Bush Today

byline.original: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: In seven rounds of global trade talks over four decades, tariff rates have been slashed by more than 75 percent. As imports became so much cheaper, trade across frontiers surged, and workers the world over produced a staggering amount of wealth.   ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In seven rounds of global trade talks over four decades, tariff rates have been slashed by more than 75 percent. As imports became so much cheaper, trade across frontiers surged, and workers the world over produced a staggering amount of wealth. The problem for the eighth round of trade talks is precisely that success: World trade has outgrown the rules written for it. The round is scheduled to end with a meeting in Brussels next week, if a bitter dispute on farm subsidies can be resolved.

headline.main: Freer World Trade Falls Victim to Its Own Success

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Moving to soften a long dispute with the United States just days ahead of a visit to this area by President Bush, the Presidents of Brazil and Argentina formally renounced the manufacture of nuclear weapons today at a meeting on their border.   ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Moving to soften a long dispute with the United States just days ahead of a visit to this area by President Bush, the Presidents of Brazil and Argentina formally renounced the manufacture of nuclear weapons today at a meeting on their border. Presidents Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil and Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina promised that their nuclear potential, the most advanced in Latin America, would be used for "exclusively peaceful ends."

headline.main: Argentina and Brazil Renounce Atomic Weapons

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: American companies are not sitting idly by as the United States negotiating team prepares to leave for the global trade talks to be held in Brussels next week. Convinced that the stakes are large, many companies are lobbying hard.    Some 14,000...
docs.lead_paragraph: American companies are not sitting idly by as the United States negotiating team prepares to leave for the global trade talks to be held in Brussels next week. Convinced that the stakes are large, many companies are lobbying hard. Some 14,000 American companies, including giants with vast international operations like I.B.M., General Motors, Honeywell, Minnesota Mining and American Express, formed the MTN Coalition in May to promote the reduction of tariffs and other trade barriers. (The initials stand for Multilateral Trade Negotiations.)

headline.main: Winners and Losers in Trade Talks

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: A "low-grade sinus infection" will prevent Barbara Bush from accompanying President Bush on his tour across South America next week, the White House said today. Instead, his daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, will make the trip on Dec. 2-8 to Brazil,...
docs.lead_paragraph: A "low-grade sinus infection" will prevent Barbara Bush from accompanying President Bush on his tour across South America next week, the White House said today. Instead, his daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, will make the trip on Dec. 2-8 to Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela. Mrs. Bush, 65 years old, spent much of the last 12 days with her husband in Mexico, Europe and the Middle East. Anna Perez, the First Lady's press secretary, said Mrs. Bush had been unable to shake the infection, which has bothered her for two to three weeks.

docs.snippet: Free trade is wonderful, most nations agree -- except for those instances where it impinges on some powerful national interest.    The Japanese bar rice imports, for instance, to protect the politically influential rice farmers. The United States...
docs.lead_paragraph: Free trade is wonderful, most nations agree -- except for those instances where it impinges on some powerful national interest. The Japanese bar rice imports, for instance, to protect the politically influential rice farmers. The United States politely insisted that the Japanese voluntarily limit the number of cars they ship to the American market. The Europeans erect walls against Japanese cars, American semiconductors and American pork and beef.

headline.main: Clash of Free Trade and National Interest
